reviews.advice: I understand EF's business model is to hire young and pay low, but I do think a bit more can be done to keep talented people at the company with more financial incentives. I did a lot of business for EF in a senior position and would have been quite happy to stay on a lot longer if I was on an extra 15-20k per year. Instead, money seems to be spent on (in my opinion) vanity projects like a business school in a castle.
reviews.cons:
Salary and career progression - EF is a fantastic company to learn skills, but once you hit a certain point it can be very difficult to move up the career ladder. As it's a very comfortable place to work, I do feel there is a little bit of gatekeeping regarding senior positions and I feel that compliance is held in higher regarded than talent. Having said that, I did have managers that I thoroughly respected and learnt from.

I made a fairly decent living with EF (compared to others I've seen on really low salaries - £25k pa in London), but at the same time I often felt that for the same effort I put into the job I'd make more elsewhere. Ultimately though, it's pretty standard for people to work at EF for a few years to then go on to higher paid jobs. Therefore, I think it's just about a fair deal for EFs employees to get trained up and go on to better things. I certainly am grateful to have been there, despite the salary not being amazing.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to share your feedback. Input like this helps us create a better workplace. We are happy to hear you enjoyed your time at EF and learned valuable skills. While we do review our compensation structure regularly, we are also working on what more can be done to retain our talent. Thank you again for taking the time to leave us a review.  We wish you the best in your future career!

reviews.pros:
With the right attitude, you will learn a lot at EF. There is a real environment of everyone wanting to step up and take on new challenges and it is this that will see you progress as a professional. 

While not perfect, I also feel EF sincerely believes in it's values and that it is a company that, despite it's size, does care about it's employees.

It may have a slightly high staff turnover due to salary (I'll get to that) but you will absolutely work with talented individuals of various levels of seniority. I often felt inspired walking into the office and had a lot of accomplished colleagues to aspire to.

reviews.advice: The students hate the way the group lessons are run. I hear nothing but complaints about the group lessons. 40 minutes/8 students + a teacher giving instruction is less than 4 minutes of total speaking practice time for each student. Then you always have the one student who tries to hog it all. For the teacher, the entire class becomes about trying to manage student talk time instead of actually working on correcting or improving the students' speech. There is no time to actually teach, or else the students will not have time to speak, get mad, and leave bad ratings. Class size needs to be halved at the minimum, to provide any value.
reviews.cons:
*Low pay by any standards. This worked really well for me living in an impoverished country with a tiny cost of living. If you are traveling around 1st world countries, this salary will never be enough for you. Maybe just a supplement in conjunction with a real job. 
*The grading is incredibly annoying. There are 5 categories that each need a numerical grade, a positive comment, and a constructive criticism. It works well if you're teaching a student once and moving on, but if you are building up a consistent clientele and teaching the same students multiple times per week for years, you run out of new things to say really fast, and your grading comments begin to sound like a broken record. "You needed to work on plural nouns two days ago... and today, you still need to work on plural nouns."

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to write a review — and for your work teaching over 5,700 classes with us! We are proud to have teachers like you who are committed to supporting our students' learning journeys. It is great to hear you enjoy the flexibility and autonomy teaching online with us has provided. We also appreciate you sharing your feedback on how group lessons are run. We always want to improve, and comments like yours are invaluable in helping us do that. Thank you again for your work and for writing a review. We hope you continue to enjoy teaching with us!

reviews.pros:
*Great flexibility
*Great autonomy
*No micromanagement. If your student ratings are high, they'll never bother you. Teach your own way, offer lesson styles and plans extraneous to the core curriculum, provide customized client service outside of the lesson plans... do your thing. If the clients are happy and returning, it will be reflected in your ratings, and you will be left free to operate. Since my training 6 years ago, I have never spoken to management once regarding my performance or what happens in my classroom. But then, my ratings are 4.97/5.0 with 5700 classes taught. They do not tend to fix what isn't broken. 
*Very kind and understanding in the event of internet or power outages. I have never felt that they didn't believe me, and they handled my sub-outs without questions or attitude. However,  my instances were very rare and real. Cry wolf, and you might find a different story.
reviews.summary: Great if you live abroad in a low-cost country

reviews.advice: Sometime trues stars need to be considered a bit more after super efforts. Sometime the management should relies on lower level employees to step further.
reviews.cons: Sometime the amazing core values face with people arrogance and this leads to big misunderstandings. Of course it happens in many companies but to waste the potential achievable with true star employees it's really a mistake.
reviews.pros: Positive environment, passionate culture, amazing core values! People at EF are sparking and the Company mission is amazing! One of the best places I've been working in in the last period (I've 20 years of experience)

reviews.advice: Cast a wide net but set the bar a little higher when hiring people - during the time I worked there, there were a good few mis-hires who didn't last beyond their probation periods.
reviews.cons: Had one boss who behaved very unprofessionally toward me, but he was then fired for his behavior. Overall the company handled it reasonably well.
reviews.pros: Great colleagues, among which I made some lifelong friends. Regular (weekly or biweekly) peer-led trainings and a genuine focus on developing employees. Upper management was mostly good; middle management was mixed (see cons).
reviews.summary: Teacher in Beijing - Decent Employer, Few Complaints

reviews.advice: Provide better housing, management and HR support to teachers in terms of bullying and general bad working relations
reviews.cons:
-run-down schools/buildings
-being thrown into marketing events without preparation
-other foreign teachers

This experience may stem directly from my own school, but during my stay at EF, the school was run-down, equipment rarely worked and the overall surrounding work environment was in a very poor building. The apartment offered was also run-down with a random room with broken objects/objects from previous owners. I think it would be good to mention that standards of health & safety and general building maintenance are different depending on the wealth of the region the school is based in (again China specific), and in general, less stringent than safety checks in the majority of western Europe. There was poor heating and the facilities looked generally un-cared for. The same could be said for the apartment we were provided - although I am unsure whether this is (a) differences in living standards between China-Europe (I hate saying this, but there is some truth to this) (b) the school placed us in a particularly run-down area (which I think may be the case).

Being thrown into marketing events without proper preparation was not a huge challenge for myself as I had a lot of public speaking experience, but I think for some teachers found it was a challenge. Be aware that you will be expected to perform for random groups of Chinese investors/families/prospective students.

It may seem odd to add 'other foreign teachers' but I think it is worth mentioning the often toxic work environment that can be created by homesick foreign teachers. My school may have been an anomaly, but teacher management was generally lacking whereby the favorite past-time was to complain about the company and criticize Chinese society in general. As an eager traveler, I found this the most grating and would hope that better teacher management was brought into place by HR. In general, the foreign teachers in your school will become your main source of social outlet so it's very important that there is a harmonious understanding between everyone.
reviews.pros:
-hires teachers without teaching qualifications
-offers further teacher training
-opportunity to travel
-good overall pay
-good work/life balance

Education First (especially Franchise schools) often gets a lot of criticism. I won't lie and say that franchise schools are at the most professional of levels, yet working at EF gave me an amazing opportunity to live in China, immerse myself in a different culture and generally have a very adventurous year. Classes come pre-planned and the students are generally lovely to teach. An apartment was included with support from local HR. Local staff were lovely and very warm/welcoming. Working at EF certainly created many warm memories for me and has fostered a strong connection between myself and Chinese culture.

reviews.cons: The pay is not so great.
reviews.pros: EF Tours is a great company to work for if you are a recent graduate. It is a company full of young people and they are always planning office events and EF wide events in different cities across North America. Travelling is a huge perk. The amount of vacation days is also great. In your first year, you get 15 paid vacations days plus 2 personal days. In year 2, you get 20 vacation days!
reviews.summary: EF is a fun company that allows you to travel and meet new people.

reviews.advice: I understand that the visa process is time consuming however perhaps modernise  internal EF working processes so that it can be done asap. Some people wait around 5-6 months after a offer has been given to go to China- this isn't necessarily a bad thing but it might be better to get the people quickly to China before the excitement of the opportunity fades as a lot of applicants have had prior teaching experience.
reviews.cons:
The pay is a little lower than their direct competitors such as Disney. Not everyone uses the events and other perks at EF china so I think pay should be a little more competitive. 

The job is what it is however EF needs to modernise their physical centres of teaching as there are some old places that are still being used today and good hygiene is hard to maintain if you end up working on a dilapidated mall based centre. 

If you recruit people from Western countries with more generous time off (UK, Ireland, Canada?) then perhaps the contracts should be a little more generous or give the people a chance to choose whether they might choose to work 4 days a week for a lower salary or 6 days a week for a higher salary. Lack of flexibility on this I believe might hinder some people from applying to EF. 

Disney have started to give bonuses to teacher who manage to retain students at Disney. Perhaps EF should be copying this because an added financial incentive gives more motivation to perform which will increase/maintain sales and revenue.
reviews.pros:
It's a safe company to work for if you're a recent graduate and there is fast promotions in place if you end of working for an wholly ef owned centre in one of the larger cities (Beijing, Guangzhou, Shenzen etc), 

Very good for people scared of travelling and working in a different country as they pretty much don't leave anything to chance and help cover all aspects. Flight ticket will be bought by EF when you head into China and the contract covers a travel stipend which you must use wisely. Also good at paying on time and paying for expenses you incur yourself before you travel however you will be advised that you will be paid in Yuan and not your home currency plus remember to keep your receipts.

reviews.advice: It would be nice to keep the bonus that you earn even if subsequently you do less hours.
reviews.cons: The pay is low. It is difficult to be eligible for pay increase. Sometimes you can lose the bonus if you don't maintain an average of sixty hours a month or positive reviews.

employerResponses.response:
Thanks for taking a few minutes to share your experience about teaching online with EF.

We’re happy to hear that you find the work rewarding, and that you’re able to meet many people from all over the world. That’s aligned with our vision of Opening the World Through Education. 

EF understands teachers value the potential to earn bonuses, and we clearly outline requirements to qualify for a bonus. Requirements are linked to academic and operational quality and quantity of classes taught. As our teachers have varying schedules, we offer different bonuses for hours taught, ranging from 20 hours through to 60 hours. 

Thanks again for your feedback, and we hope that you continue to find your job to be rewarding.

reviews.pros: You get to meet with and work with people from around the world. I found it to be very rewarding. It is very flexible - you choose your own hours.
reviews.summary: Flexible hours and enjoyable work but the pay is low

reviews.advice:
Increase salaries and weed out teachers who don't know what they are doing. 
Fix the scheduling system, so students can see our availability. 
Stop hiring teachers who are not qualified and who are bringing down the reputation of the industry
reviews.cons:
- base salary is £0.03 above minimum wage, even if you have 20 years of experience
- communication from centre managers and representatives is condescending
- technology often fails on their side and teachers are penalized
- poor pay for student no shows
reviews.pros:
+ able to set own schedule
+ nice students
+ 95% adults

reviews.advice: EF has always been a company with high turnover. Some of it is because of the mobile lifestyle of expats, but even the locals have relatively high turnover for what is supposedly a good job for them. You should ask yourselves why it is so hard for you to keep your human resources compared to your competitors.
reviews.cons:
Actively laid off native speakers during covid because we make literally 3x what the local teachers do.
Regularly claims to be "best in industry" in onboarding. Truthfully, they're better than every local school, but worse than every international school in terms of quality and pay. I suspect Wall Street English is better, since their pay and hiring process is more rigorous.
To reiterate, pay is among the lowest in the industry.
The main item: this job is not for everybody. If you can't maintain high energy around 10-15 young children for a few hours six days a week, you will not last long here. As a native speaker, your job is not to provide quality instruction; it's to generate a lot of excitement in the children and the parents. You can be fully qualified to teach in international high schools but fail here if your disposition is not right for the job.
EF Kids and Teens is where all the jobs are when there is a posting. I've never seen an ad for the adult centers.
Kept trying to say I had verbally "agreed" to giving up 6-day bonus pay when I signed a contract amendment to go hourly, even though I had email evidence I specifically stated I was not agreeing to other changes. I never did receive a bonus for those three weeks.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your feedback. It's our understanding that no teachers were laid off in any of our Indonesia schools during COVID-19. We also understand that this role is not for everyone and that it does require individuals to have a certain level of energy in the classroom but we have seen numerous individual teachers bring their own teaching styles into the classroom and succeed. If you would like to discuss your experience in more detail please contact our Director of Operations at christopher.lloyd@ef.id. There's always room for growth so appreciate your feedback and wish you the best in your future endeavors.

reviews.pros:
If you're a native English speaker with a pulse and a bachelor's degree, you're hired! (pre-covid, and you may need to pay for a TEFL certification course)
One-month severance pay was given even though the contract doesn't require or mention it.
